title: 113_hr3577
content: A commission called the "Commission on Health Care Savings through Innovative Wireless Technologies" is established in the legislative branch. The Commission's duties are outlined in the Act. The Commission on Health Care Savings through Innovative Wireless Technologies is tasked with examining cost savings, scientific research, payment models, and options for Congress related to increasing the use of wireless health information technologies in the United States health care system. The Commission on Health Care Savings through Innovative Wireless Technologies is tasked with examining options for Congress and Federal agencies to promote innovation in wireless health information technologies, identify barriers to marketplace entry, recommend integration of these technologies into Federal health care programs, and propose a comprehensive program for their establishment and financing. The Commission on Health Care Savings through Innovative Wireless Technologies is focused on promoting the integration of wireless health information technologies into Federal health care programs. They aim to develop cost estimate approaches for assessing cost savings from increased use of these technologies by patients, caregivers, and health care providers in the United States. The Commission on Health Care Savings through Innovative Wireless Technologies focuses on integrating wireless health information technologies into Federal health care programs. SEC. 3. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission on Health Care Savings through Innovative Wireless Technologies is composed of 19 individuals with expertise in wireless health information technologies. They are appointed by various officials within 45 days of the enactment of the Act. The Commission on Health Care Savings through Innovative Wireless Technologies is made up of experts in wireless health information technologies, including representatives from health care providers, group health plans, health information technology vendors, small businesses in the industry, research institutions, patient advocacy groups, health care professionals, venture capital investors, and individuals who have received health care treatment involving wireless health information. The Commission on Health Care Savings through Innovative Wireless Technologies consists of experts in wireless health information technologies. Members are appointed for life, serve without pay, and must meet at least nine times. The Chairperson is elected by the members, and nine members constitute a quorum for meetings. DIRECTOR AND STAFF OF COMMISSION; EXPERTS AND CONSULTANTS. The Commission shall have a Director appointed by the Commission, paid at level 4 of the Executive Schedule. Staff appointments follow title 5, United States Code. The Commission may procure temporary services under section 3109(b) of title 5, United States Code. The Commission may request personnel from Federal agencies to assist in carrying out its duties under this Act on a reimbursable basis. The Commission has the power to request personnel from Federal agencies to assist in carrying out its duties under this Act on a reimbursable basis. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, and receive evidence as needed. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission. The Commission can obtain information from US departments or agencies and accept gifts or bequests as specified in appropriation Acts. The Commission has the authority to accept gifts, bequests, or devises of money and property for its work. It can use the United States mails and receive administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services. The Commission also has contract authority as provided. The Commission has contract authority to compensate agencies or persons for services without regard to certain statutes. The Commission is required to submit interim reports to the President, Congress, and relevant agencies within 9 months of the final member's appointment, along with a final report within 18 months. The final report must include findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislation and administrative actions. The Commission will terminate 60 days after submitting the final report.
